sentence: These episodes could be very extreme so she (thankfully) began therapy and medication.
I keep getting asked what my goal for treatment is from both  my pdoc in my bipolar medication group which also has a small therapy element .
I have *not* found an acceptable medication regimen yet, and since the diagnosis, I have progressed into ultra-rapid cycling.
I think giving blood reduced my medications levels in my bloodstream, and thus, exposed me to the 'original' state of myself that was prone to these cycles.

I know I need to talk to a psychiatrist about all of this, but the psychiatrist I'm currently seeing only sees me for medication management, and I only see her once every 3 months for a follow up, and each follow up is 15-20 minutes long to determine if she should renew my prescription.
Hopefully a good pdoc and proper meds will help but I can't wait for that.
Could this actually be medicine-related?

I've had ADHD most of my life, and I've managed it semi-effectively (at times) alternatively through self-imposed organizational tools and habits (which work for short periods, usually), medication (which I can seldom afford now that I'm on my own), and extensions and incompletes from my professors (which I hate, but is usually what I end up needing).
So I am hypomanic, been seeing my psychiatrist and meds being adjusted etc....

And what do I even say when I get to the hospital I feel like they're going to treat me like a goddamn basket case and I'm scared and embarrassed that I let things get to this point and I don't know if I should tell my dad because that's just time and money out of his day and I don't want him to get mad at me because I'm notorious for not taking my medication shit i don't know what to fucking do at all and I don't want to fuck myself over today PLEASE HELP!
I took headache meds, sinus meds, did a NeilMed sinus rinse, and took an Epsom salt bath.
I see a psychiatrist for medication management, and I don't see a therapist.

Just a quick post before I go to sleep, so apologies for late replies/not being 100% clear:

Over the last three/four days, I've gone from about 75% (of what was normal, pre meds) depressed, to a pretty solid hypomanic.
I went through some rough patches as I tried to find a medication combination that worked for me, but (with the help of my psychiatrist) I found a combination that worked well.
**The problem now:** I just entered a manic episode about a week ago that has been one of the worst episodes since I started taking this better medication combination.
The disease makes it worse, but I think the problem is that, underneath all the symptoms and the medication, I'm just a worthless little pussy.
"The DSM IV-TR has a clause that states “medication-induced mania” is not to be considered bipolar."

On page 368 heading "Criteria for hypomanic episode" there's a note, it reads


Note: Hypomanic-like episodes that are clearly caused by somatic antidepressant treatment (e.g., medication, electroconvulsive therapy, light therapy) should not count toward a diagnosis of Bipolar II Disorder.
** She wants me on lamitral which are anti seizure meds.
Anyways, now that I'm 25, having started medication two days ago, I'm starting to feel a lot of resentment and disappointment.
So friends, what is your medication(s) nightmare?
I'm not sure if it's my medications or I'm just losing my mind with racing thoughts, but I will go into another room and forget why I got up in the first place.
have mood stabilizers and other medications for bipolar 2 been worth the risk of side effects?

I try to handle it myself with anxiety meds only when needed and marijuana (which calms me down and helps me think straight) and to just work through everything, but I'd say we all know that doesn't always work as expected and can even backfire.
I know the mental health team and medication is what i want.
From both the transition and the medicine itself.
No meds.
I've agreed not to move anytime soon - added extra therapy and another medication and my doctor has approved a week off work for me to get to a place where I can focus again.

I've been hypomanic for the past few weeks and despite medication increases (going from lamictal 100mg to 200mg and seroquel 25mg to 100mg), exercise, and eating right, I keep going up and up and up and up.

... not to sound dire, but even when you think you have EVERYTHING going - insight, doctor access, medication, general health and employment, supportive partner and friends - this shit comes back and hits you and WILL topple things.

One or two of you may understand what it is to have your affect blunted for most of TEN YEARS, your sexual desire coming out for MAYBE one week every three months, and wondering every day if it's the medication, the situation or YOU.
It is now totally out of my medication regime....

The lamotrigine has been my current medication for the past 5+ years, so it is interesting to see that I am feeling even better now that I am taking the N-acetylcysteine as well.

In a nutshell
I have a long history of depression, self mutilation, binging, purging, alcoholism, drug use, medication use & abuse for several mental illnesses.
Between insurance, medication, and therapy, (not to mention my student loan payments) my paycheck takes a BIG cut.
I lost my insurance last summer, so I stopped treatment and my medications.
I probably should be, although every medication I have tried and the subsequent "loading period" has felt like a disaster and seemed to make things worse.
I can try to understand it through the help of my doctors, my therapist, and my medication.
I don't think it's the meds, but I don't think I'm going into a mood swing or anything.
New meds: Lithium (450mg) and Lamictal (25mg 3x a week to build up slowly).
I had some medication changes, (took me off Lexapro, introduced Lamictal and Serequel).

I have since gone back on meds (had an insurance problem, plus I'm sure you guys know how it is with the going on and off meds) and am starting to feel more stable, besides being heartbroken/depressed and crying A LOT.
Also I had to come clean to my parents for the first time about my diagnosis (Bipolar 1) and the medication I'm taking.
This is impossible for me without paying out of pocket, because my medication expenses are only $180, and no doctor anywhere will charge $413 for a visit even if they accept SOC (which is rare).
I feel like I have had an endless list of diagnoses and medication.
No money means I cant drive to town (I live on a rural property) to see my pdoc, who I can't pay, and be prescribed medication, which I really really need.
He is a hell of a lot luckier than many people on here in that my folks will pay for his docs and meds.
So I think I have found the right medicine combo of 200mg lamotrigine, 12.5 of sertraline, and 5mg focalin.

Then I start to wonder how valid the entire basis of mental illness is when I've tried every traditional medical treatment and various medication combinations and had only few month long periods of "normal" ever in the last nine years.
I'll keep taking them every night before bed until I am clearly out of the woods - it's a lot easier being able to sleep through the worst of the medication's effects.

I have another P-doc appointment next week AND am starting weekly therapy, plus the drug copays incurred with a medication change (dropped depakote, titrating up onto lamictal, upped abilify, unchanged cymbalta.)
I am just out of a meds-induced mild depressive state.

I pay rent, cable/internet, most of our food costs, every time we go out for drinks.... plus my meds, food/treats/vet visits for my dog, gas for my car and motorcycle (luckily that one's cheap), my doctor's bills and bills for all the blood work I have to do all the damn time... but we get by.

The past two years have been a huge journey of acceptance, proper medication, recovery, and stability and then POOF, this wonderful dream girl shows up in my life!
.....tl;dr mixed episodes and no meds might be driving me beyond mad.
Its not my meds it's my god damn endocrine system and she knows it.
I know a lot about Bipolar, medications, routines, symptoms of episodes to watch out for.
Since I finally had something in my life that I was determined not to lose (people don't always stick around that long), I decided t give meds a try again.
I also thought that it was the meds that were making me feel slow/dull.
Or is this not medication related?
It's probably my meds so there's not a lot I can do until they stabilize (they just changed yet again 2 weeks ago).
Instead we had a really amazing conversation about people are so closed minded these days about mental illness and medication and all that.
I had become very stiff and shakey and the medicine seemed to be doing little to help.
I need advice, possible other medications and even just comfort.
Doing very well with CBT and medication.

After six years of relative stability on the medication and after asking my psychiatrist multiple times if there was any chance of going medication free, I've decided that it's time to give it a shot.
I've been trying to make myself go and do things besides sit and watch tv, my pdoc told me there was only so much medication could do (crazy right, out of a pdoc?).
I just tried to talk to my parents about it, and Dad is really anti-medication.
What the fuck do I do about this, like what medications/other coping mechanisms have worked for you?
My mother keeps telling my grandparents I refuse to go to work, I'm on FMLA to get through my medication changes.
Because of this he disregards anything that the traditional western medicine world brings to the table.

Even if it's not medicine side effect related.
Is this normal for seroquel and/or meds in general?
We used a cheerio and a medicine cup, haha.
With this year and a half of being off medication I have smoked weed on occasion  and while sometimes anxious for the most part I do not have any problems at all anymore.
A little over two months ago I went off all the meds I was on.
This is a great medicine for me but it doesn't go the distance because I'm still pretty scattered.
Bad medicine.
I'm going back soon for a full assessment and diagnosis and to get meds.
Maybe even other medications.
But I wasn't sure if that would be the best medication for my symptoms.
